Civil Rights

Protesting / Freedom of Assembly

What to know about your rights when participating in protests

Your Rights

5 rights in this scenario

You have a fundamental right to gather with others to protest, march, and voice political viewpoints. This is protected as free speech. Peaceful assembly means no violence or property destruction. Police cannot prevent or disperse peaceful protesters without lawful justification (like blocking traffic).

Source: 1st Amendment - Assembly and Petition; 14th Amendment

You can protest on sidewalks, parks, public plazas, and other government property. These are traditional public forums for speech. However, authorities can enforce time, place, and manner restrictions if they apply equally to all groups and don't target your message. Permits may be required for large gatherings but cannot be denied based on viewpoint.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 1st Amendment; Public Forum Doctrine

You can photograph and record video and audio of anything visible and audible from a public space. This includes police, protests, and government activities. You do not need permission. However, don't block others, trespass, or interfere with police work. Recording is important documentation of protests and police conduct.

ðŸ’¡ This right has state-specific variations. Select a state to see relevant details.

Source: 1st Amendment - Free Speech; Constitutional Right to Record Public Events

If arrested at a protest, you still have full constitutional rights. You have the right to remain silentâ€”do not answer questions without a lawyer present. Request a lawyer immediately and clearly. Ask why you're being arrested. Do not resist, even if you believe the arrest is unlawful. Challenge it in court later with your lawyer.

Source: 5th Amendment, 6th Amendment, Miranda Rights

The government cannot restrict your speech based on its viewpoint, message, or content. You can hold signs, chant, and speak about controversial topics. You cannot be arrested for offensive speech alone (with narrow exceptions like true threats). Your speech is protected even if others find it offensive or disagree strongly.

Source: 1st Amendment - Free Speech Clause

Educational Disclaimer: This tool is for educational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. For specific legal questions, consult a licensed attorney in your jurisdiction.
